question: A 5-year-old boy presents with fatigue, pallor, and recurrent infections. CBC shows anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with lymphoblast predominance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A 2-year-old child presents with an abdominal mass crossing the midline. Laboratory studies show elevated urinary catecholamines. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive ataxia, headache, and vomiting. MRI reveals a mass in the cerebellum with cystic and solid components. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 3-year-old boy has a unilateral palpable abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. Ultrasound confirms a renal mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A 6-year-old child with Down syndrome presents with fatigue, bleeding gums, and petechiae. CBC reveals blasts positive for myeloperoxidase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
An 8-year-old boy presents with bone pain worse at night and relieved by NSAIDs. X-ray reveals a radiolucent lesion with central nidus. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
A 4-year-old boy presents with visual disturbances and endocrine dysfunction. MRI shows a suprasellar mass with calcifications. Which tumor is most likely responsible?
A 10-year-old boy presents with localized swelling and pain in the distal femur. Imaging shows a sunburst pattern and Codman triangle. Which of the following is most likely?
